'''US Nuclear Corporation''' is a US [[Radioactivity|radiation detection]] [[holding company]] headquartered in [[Canoga Park, CA]]<ref>http://new.usnuclearcorp.com/contact-us/</ref> specializing in the development and manufacturing of radiation detection instrumentation. It supplies instrumentation to [[nuclear power plant]]s, national laboratories, government agencies, [[homeland security]], [[military]] and [[weapon maker]]s, universities<ref>see e.g. http://cancerres.aacrjournals.org/content/41/11_Part_1/4378.full-text.pdf</ref> and schools, research companies, hospitals, as well as [[energy companies]].
==Products== Products include:<ref>http://www.marketwatch.com/investing/stock/ucle</ref> *Radiation Air and Water Monitors *[[Aerial reconnaissance]] *[[alpha radiation|alpha]], beta, gamma and [[tritium monitor]]s *[[Unmanned aerial vehicle|Drone]]RAD aerial [[Radioactivity|radiation detection]]<ref>http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/southern-california-commercial-uav-company-teams-up-with-radiation-detection-company-otcbb-ucle-2159384.htm</ref><ref>http://tech-associates.com/product-info/DroneRad.pdf</ref> *Vehicle monitors, personnel monitors, exit monitors and room monitors<ref>https://www.dhs.gov/sites/default/files/publications/PortRadPortalMons-MSR_0315-508.pdf</ref> *[[Radon air monitor]]s and radon switch products *Handheld [[survey meter]]s and personal [[dosimeter]]s *Pocket micro-R meters *[[Port security]] equipment *software solutions
==Operating divisions== US Nuclear Corp has three divisions:<ref>http://new.usnuclearcorp.com/investor-relations/</ref> *Technical Associates, founded in 1946 as a spin off from the [[Manhattan Project]], built the first industrial grade radiation monitors.<ref>http://www.tech-associates.com/corporateprofile/corporateprofile.pdf</ref> *[[Overhoff Technology]] Corporation, design and manufacturing of high quality [[tritium]] monitors<ref>http://www.overhoff.com/</ref> *Electronic Control Concepts (ECC), [[X-ray]] equipment <ref>http://eccxray.com/</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/us-nuclear-corp-ucle-makes-third-acquisition-as-part-aggressive-growth-through-acquisition-2156067.htm|date=2016-09-07|title=US Nuclear Corp. UCLE Makes Third Acquisition as Part of Aggressive Growth-Through-Acquisition Strategy }}</ref>

<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:ARUP-building.jpg|thumb|right|300px|[[ARUP Laboratories]]' main facility in Research Park.]] --> The '''University of Utah Research Park''', also known as '''Bionic Valley''',<ref>{{cite book|last1=Berlin|first1=Leslie|title=The Man Behind the Microchip: Robert Noyce and the Invention of Silicon Valley|date=1 November 2006|publisher=Oxford University Press|pages=402|accessdate=1 April 2017}}</ref><ref name="latimes">{{cite news|last1=Curry|first1=Bill|title=Utah University Spurs Creation of 'Bionic Valley' : Artificial Body Parts May Aid Thousands|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1985-11-10/news/mn-3370_1_artificial-kidney|accessdate=1 April 2017|work=Los Angeles Times|date=10 November 1985}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Sobel|first1=Robert|title=The Great Boom 1950-2000: How a Generation of Americans Created the Most Prosperous Society|date=21 March 2002|publisher=Macmillan}}</ref> is located on the campus of the [[University of Utah]] in [[Salt Lake City]], [[United States]]. The facility has helped create many businesses based on the work of university scientists over the years. Research Park now houses more than forty companies alongside sixty-nine academic departments and employs more than 7,500 people.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Stefoff|first1=Rebecca|last2=Mead|first2=Wendy|title=Utah: Celebrate the State|date=1 September 2009|publisher=Marshall Cavendish|pages=144|accessdate=1 April 2017}}</ref> The annual in-state productivity of park residents exceeds $550 million.<ref name="Development">{{cite web |title=Economic Development: Research Park |url=http://www.research.utah.edu/econ/ |publisher=[[University of Utah]] |accessdate=2009-04-08 }}</ref>
==History== In 1968, the Utah state legislature allocated 320 acres along the [[Bonneville Shoreline Trail]] to develop a [[research park]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Title 53B Chapter 17|url=http://le.utah.gov/xcode/Title53B/Chapter17/C53B-17-P5_1800010118000101.pdf|website=Utah Code|publisher=Utah State Legislature|accessdate=1 April 2017}}</ref> Research Park was intended to stimulate economic development within the State of Utah and encourage students who graduate from the University of Utah to stay in Salt Lake City by providing research jobs.<ref>{{cite web|title=East Bench Master Plan|url=http://www.slcdocs.com/Planning/Projects/EBMP/DraftPlanApril2016/6_RegionalActivityCenter.pdf|website=Plan Salt Lake City|publisher=Salt Lake City Corporation|accessdate=1 April 2017|date=April 2016}}</ref>
In 1982, when the successful implantation of the [[Jarvik 7]] artificial heart attracted international headlines, artificial organ and medical device research and development at the University of Utah led [[Science Digest]] and the [[New York Times]] to nickname Salt Lake City the "Bionic Valley": "the epicenter of a bioengineering effort that promises to shake up the entire health-care system."<ref>{{cite news|title=Utah's 'Bionic Valley' Produces Another Life-Changing Medical Device|url=http://www.matr.net/article-39035.html|accessdate=1 April 2017|agency=Montana Associated Technology Roundtables|date=20 April 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Zaslowsky|first1=Dyan|title=Regional Job Roundup - Mountain|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/10/13/jobs/regional-job-roundup-mountain.html|website=The New York Times|accessdate=1 April 2017|date=13 October 1985}}</ref>
==Companies== The following companies and institutes are current or former residents of research park: *[[Evans and Sutherland]] *[[Sarcos]] *[[Goldman Sachs]] *[[ARUP Laboratories]] *[[NPS Pharmaceuticals]] *[[BioFire Diagnostics]] *[[Myriad Genetics]] *[[Echelon Research Laboratories]] *University of Utah Center for Reproductive Medicine *Utah Poison Control Center *[[Rockwell Collins]] *[[Huntsman Chemical Corporation]] *[[University Neuropsychiatric Institute]] *[[Wasatch Advisors]] *[[Cross Creek Capital]] *[[Navigen Pharmaceuticals]] *[[Recursion Pharmaceuticals]] *[[Williams Companies]] *[[Cyberkinetics|Blackrock Microsystems]] *[[Actavis]] *[[Verum TCS, LLC]] *[[SWSA Medical Ventures, LLC]] *[[BTG plc|Protherics]] *[[Alucent Biomedical]]

{{Infobox organization | name = Z.Smith Reynolds Foundation| founded_date = | founder = Mary Reynolds Babcock | location = [[Winston-Salem, North Carolina]], United States | origins = Reynolds family tobacco fortune | key_people = [[Leslie Winner]], executive director | area_served = Piedmont Triad, North Carolina | focus = Social Justice & Equity, Environment, Education, Community and Economic Development, Democracy | method = Grants, Funding | revenue = $21,829,355<ref name="Ratings">{{cite web | url=http://990s.foundationcenter.org/990pf_pdf_archive/586/586038145/586038145_201612_990PF.pdf | title=Z. Smith Reynolds Foundation Inc. | date=2 June 2017 | website=Foundation Center | accessdate=28 November 2017 }}</ref> | revenue_year = 2016 | expenses = $20,643,901<ref name="Ratings" /> | expenses_year = 2016 | endowment = peak of $470 million<ref name="pj">{{cite news |url=http://www.philanthropyjournal.org/nc/ncnews/z-smith-reynolds-focusing-change |publisher=''The Philanthropy Journal'' |date=2009-01-14|pages= |title=Z. Smith Reynolds focusing on change|first=Todd |last=Cohen}}</ref> | num_volunteers = | owner = | Non-profit_slogan = Improving the quality of life for all North Carolinians | homepage = {{URL|http://www.zsr.org}} | tax_exempt = | dissolved = | footnotes = }}
The '''Z. Smith Reynolds Foundation''' was formed by [[R. J. Reynolds]]' daughter, Mary Reynolds Babcock, and her siblings to honor their brother, [[Zachary Smith Reynolds]], who was murdered at the age of 20 at the Reynolds family home, [[Reynolda House]].<ref name="wfu">{{cite news |url=http://www.wfu.edu/history/HST_WFU/monuments.htm |publisher=''[[Wake Forest University]] Magazine'' |date=July 1970|pages= |title=M O N U M E N T S of Brick and Learning |first=Dave |last=Roberts}}</ref> The foundation to this day gives away millions of dollars annually in the state of [[North Carolina]]. In 2008, the fund gave away $18 million in grants, including $2 million to [[Wake Forest University]].<ref name="pj"/>
During the [[2008 economic crisis]], the value of the foundation's trust declined 30% from its high of $470 million in November 2007.<ref name="pj"/> The foundation subsequently announced plans to revise the way it processes grants.<ref name="pj"/> The foundation, which has focused on affordable housing, immigration, education and the environment, will focus its environmental grants on water, energy and growth.<ref name="pj"/> The foundation's grants will be slightly less (at $16 million) than the $18 million given in 2008, but cuts will be steeper in 2010 and 2011.<ref name="pj2">{{cite news |url=http://www.philanthropyjournal.org/nc/ncnews/reynolds-foundation-holding-steady-%E2%80%9809 |publisher=''The Philanthropy Journal'' |date=2009-04-13|pages= |title=Reynolds Foundation holding steady in '09|first=Ret |last=Boney}}</ref>
In the past, the foundation has paid for a study about North Carolina's Work First [[welfare reform]] program, conducted by [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]] researchers.<ref name="welfare reform">{{cite news |url=http://www.unc.edu/depts/welfare/entire_book.doc |publisher=''[[UNC-Chapel Hill]] Odum Research Institute'' |year=2002|pages=|format=.doc |title=Meeting Challenges: North Carolina Responds to Welfare Reform, 1996–2001 |first=Christine |last=Kelleher}}</ref>
